items.question: What is Umbral?
items.answer: Umbral is an independent analytical platform that monitors regime transformation dynamics in Venezuela. We use historical data, academic indices, and verified journalistic sources to inform about possible political change scenarios.

items.question: Where does the data come from?
items.answer: Our main sources include V-Dem (Varieties of Democracy), the ERT Dataset by Maerz et al., DEED (Democratic Episodes Event Dataset), human rights organizations like Foro Penal, and independent Venezuelan media such as Efecto Cocuyo, El Pitazo, and Runrunes.

items.question: Are the probabilities predictions?
items.answer: No. The probabilities presented are analytical estimates based on historical patterns of regime transitions globally. They do not constitute predictions or forecasts. Political events are inherently unpredictable.

items.question: How often is the information updated?
items.answer: The news feed is updated continuously. Political prisoner indicators are updated weekly based on human rights organization reports. Scenarios are reviewed monthly.

items.question: Is Umbral affiliated with any party or movement?
items.answer: No. Umbral is an independent data analysis platform. We do not promote any specific political agenda nor are we affiliated with parties, governments, or political organizations.

whatIs.title: What is Umbral?
whatIs.content: Umbral is an independent analytical platform designed to monitor and contextualize regime transformation dynamics in Venezuela. We combine rigorous academic data, historical indicators, and monitoring of verified journalistic sources to offer an informed view of possible political change scenarios.

scope.title: Scope and Purpose
scope.content: Our goal is to democratize access to quality analytical information about the Venezuelan political situation. We do not make predictions nor promote political agendas. We provide tools for citizens, journalists, and researchers to interpret signals and historical patterns.

methodology.title: Methodology
methodology.content: We use a multi-source approach combining academic democracy indices (V-Dem), historical regime episode datasets (ERT, DEED), independent media monitoring, and human rights organization data. Scenario probabilities are derived from analysis of global historical patterns of regime transitions.

acknowledgements.title: Acknowledgements
acknowledgements.content: This project builds on the work of researchers, journalists, and human rights defenders who rigorously document Venezuelan reality. We especially thank the V-Dem teams, the ERT Dataset authors, and Venezuelan civil society organizations.

democraticTransition.name: Democratic Transition
democraticTransition.description: The 1958 moment: path to full liberalization

revertedLiberalization.name: Reverted Liberalization
revertedLiberalization.description: The fragile spring: reforms aborted like in 1948

preemptedDemocraticTransition.name: Preempted Democratic Transition
preemptedDemocraticTransition.description: The glass ceiling: electoral victory blocked

stabilizedElectoralAutocracy.name: Stabilized Electoral Autocracy
stabilizedElectoralAutocracy.description: The branch on steroids: new authoritarian equilibrium

phases.title: Alignment of multiple conditions
phases.description: Opposition achieves strategic unity while coordinated international pressure, primarily American, increases. Economic collapse fractures the chavista elite.

phases.title: Defection of key military sectors
phases.description: Mid-rank officers break with the regime. A supervised transition similar to Venezuela's 1958 Puntofijo Pact is established.

phases.title: Deep institutional reforms
phases.description: Constitutional reform subordinating armed forces to civilian power. Transitional justice mechanisms and accountability processes are implemented.

phases.title: Economic recovery and free elections
phases.description: Macroeconomic stabilization with international support. First fully competitive elections with robust international observation.

phases.title: Democracy as the only game in town
phases.description: Democracy establishes itself as the only viable governance model. Accountability institutions and the rule of law are strengthened.

phases.title: Recognized opposition triumph
phases.description: Opposition wins elections and results are recognized after sustained internal and international pressure.

phases.title: Chavista deep state resistance
phases.description: Judiciary and security forces maintain loyalty to chavismo. Key reforms are blocked generating systematic ungovernability, similar to Argentina 1971-1974.

phases.title: Administrative and economic failure
phases.description: Inability to govern effectively generates acute economic crisis. Population loses faith in new government due to lack of tangible results.

phases.title: Opposition coalition collapse
phases.description: Internal disunity and power disputes weaken the government. Chavista sectors capitalize on social discontent.

phases.title: Return of authoritarian control
phases.description: Manufactured or real crisis justifies military or judicial intervention. Democratic transition is partially or totally reversed.

phases.title: New equilibrium post-28J
phases.description: After events like the July 28, 2024 electoral fraud, a more economically liberal but politically limited competitive autocracy is established.

phases.title: Selective international legitimation
phases.description: Rapprochement with Trump administration and other international actors interested in oil and migration. Economic concessions without real political change.

phases.title: Control through strategic intimidation
phases.description: Surgical persecution of key opposition leaders. Mass emigration continues as political escape valve (8+ million Venezuelans abroad).

phases.title: Periodic elections without real competition
phases.description: Regular elections held with predetermined results. CNE and TSJ operate as regime arms. Viable opposition candidates are disqualified.

phases.title: Consolidation of a tropical Orbanism
phases.description: An electoral autocracy model stabilizes with modest economic recovery. Clientelist resource distribution maintains chavista coalition unity.

phases.title: Promising initial liberalization
phases.description: Favorable conditions generate optimism. Peaceful protests and greater media space are allowed, similar to 1936-1945 period (Gómez's death until before Trienio).

phases.title: Cosmetic changes without real transformation
phases.description: Limited institutional reforms that don't alter fundamental power structures. Military and chavista economic elite maintain intact privileges.

phases.title: Blockage from armed forces
phases.description: Military and security apparatus sectors reject reforms threatening their control over illegal economy (gold, drugs) and political power.

phases.title: Economic or security crisis
phases.description: Deep economic collapse or security crisis (real or fabricated) generates panic. Conservative sectors demand iron fist.

phases.title: Violent reversion 1948-style
phases.description: Abrupt military intervention similar to the coup that ended the 1948 Trienio Adeco. Full authoritarian control is restored eliminating democratic advances.

phases.title: Total abandonment of electoral pretenses
phases.description: Hard military coup or radical revolutionary figure displaces current leadership. Any democratic facade is abandoned, similar to 1948-1958.

phases.title: Massive and indiscriminate repression
phases.description: Large-scale arbitrary detentions. Forced disappearances. State violence against journalists, human rights defenders and opponents. Total censorship.

phases.title: Extreme international isolation
phases.description: Widespread diplomatic rupture and severe sanctions. Venezuela becomes pariah state with links only to Russia, Iran, China. Economy in free fall.

phases.title: Regional-scale humanitarian crisis
phases.description: Widespread famine, non-existent public services, mass migration exceeds 10-12 million. Internal armed conflict or paramilitarization.

phases.title: Loss of governance capacity
phases.description: Regime does not effectively control territory. Zones under control of irregular armed groups. Possible external intervention or territorial fragmentation.

revertedLiberalization.name: Reverted Liberalization
revertedLiberalization.description: An episode of liberalization in an autocracy that failed to transition to democracy. While political space opened significantly after Gómez's death (the 'Post-Gómez opening') and during the Trienio Adeco, the process was abruptly reversed by the 1948 military coup, returning the country to closed autocracy.

regressedAutocracy.name: Regressed Autocracy
regressedAutocracy.description: A deepening of authoritarianism within an existing autocratic regime. Following the 1948 coup, the military junta rapidly dismantled the previous democratic institutions and restricted civil liberties, moving the regime further away from any potential democratization.

democraticTransition.name: Democratic Transition
democraticTransition.description: A successful episode of liberalization in an autocracy that resulted in a transition to democracy. Triggered by the fall of Pérez Jiménez and solidified by the Punto Fijo pact, this period established the competitive electoral institutions that defined the democratic era.

democraticBreakdown.name: Democratic Breakdown
democraticBreakdown.description: An episode of autocratization in a democracy that resulted in a transition to autocracy. Beginning with the election of Hugo Chávez and the 1999 constitutional changes, the regime experienced a gradual erosion of democratic norms ('preempted democratic transition' turned breakdown) that culminated in a closed authoritarian regime under Maduro.
